The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

div.head: Hall's Sanitary Washable Distemper
div.p: Made in 70 Colors
An artistic wall covering.
This celebrated water paint is made in two qualities for Inside and Outside work

HALL’S SANITARY WASHABLE DISTEMPER is rapidly superseding wall papers in all tastefully furnished homes. It is made in 70 artistic tints, and only requires the addition of water to make it ready for use. It is quickly and easily applied with a whitewash brush, with half the labour and at one third the cost of paint. HALL’S DISTEMPER ensures cleanliness, and is pleasing to the eye. It appeals alike to artistic and practical house decoration. HALL’S DISTEMPER is of special value in hot climates. div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: ITALIAN EARTHQUAKE.
SCENES OF DISTRESS.
KING VICTOR’S ACTIVE SYMPATHY.
div.p: ROME, September 11. The Minister of Public Works has proceeded o Calabria with a relief train. The country is lescribed as one vast cemetery. Villages have ieen wiped out. The putrefying corpses are ittering the ground. The demented population nobbed a train clamouring for help. Fissures or miles along the land are visible. (Reuter)
CATANZABO, September 11. King Victor Emmanuel has arrived at Monteleone, the centre of the earthquake.

CATANZABO, September 11. King Victor Emmanuel is going from village o village in his automobile, personally questioning the sufferers and encouraging the authorities to work for the relieving of the istress. (Reuter)
ROME, September 11. The King has left for Calabria, where the istrese is great. In some villages the death ite is 90 (Hawu >

div.head: TARTARS AND KURDS.
A GENERAL RISING
div.p: TIFLIS, September 11. The whole Tartar population in the Zange- rsk district has risen and joined 4,000 armed srsian Kurds The Viceroy has made urgent presentations to the Persian authorities. (Reuter

div.head: THE BAKU REVOLT
FOUR REGIMENTS ARRIVE
div.p: BAKU, September 11. Four regiments of infantry with artillery ad cavalry have arrived here (Reuter) BAKU, September 11. The disorders continue. (Hawu)

div.head: THE ANGLO JAPANESE TREATY
div.p: LONDON, September 11. It is understood that the Anglo-Japanese treaty will be published simultaneously here and at Tokio at the end of the week. (Reuter)

div.head: ROYAL VISIT TO INDIA.
div.p: LONDON, September 11. The Prince and Princess of Wales will leave Genoa on board the Renown on the 21st October and arrive in Messina on the 23rd. They will stay six hours at Port Said on the 27th and twenty-four hours at Aden on the 3rd November. They will arrive at Bombay on the 9th November. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW YORK TRAIN DERAILED.TEN KILLED, THIRTY INJURED.
div.p: NEW YORK, September 11. A crowded train on the elevated railway has been derailed. A car fell into the street, and there are ten killed and thirty injured. ( Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH ARMY MANCEUVRES.
div.p: PARIS, September 11. M. Loubet was present at the Eastern mance uvrea. In a speech he expressed his faith in the loyalty of the army. (Havas)

div.head: THE MADRID ELECTIONS
div.p: MADRID, September 11. The ministerials have the majority at the legislative elections. (Havas)

div.head: THE ST. LEGER RACE.
div.p: LONDON, September 11. All M Blanc’s horses have been scratched for the St Leger. (.Sswfcr LONDON, September 11. The rough weather on the Channel prevent¬ ed the racehorse Val from crowing, and it cannot, therefore, compete in the St Lifer.

div.head: AFTER THE WAR.SEVERAL RESIGNATIONS.TOKIO QUIET AGAIN
div.p: TOKIO, September 11.
The Minister of Interior and the Chief of Police have resigned. Prince Fukushima left Kaiyuan in order to meet the Russians and to arrange an armistice. (Ruster)
LONDON, September 11. The “Daily Telegraph” learns from Tokio that it is stated that Generals Nodgi and Nodzou have resigned. ( Reuter)
TOKIO, September 11.
Order is re-established 1. ( Haves)

div.head: RUSSIAN RECEPTION OF PEACE.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, September 11. The announcement of peace was received with great jubilation by the Russian troops in Manchuria. President Roosevelt was every-where toasted. The soldiers are apprehensive of the situation at home and prefer to remain in Manchuria. (Reuter)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: THE PLAGUE.—Yesterday’s bulletin reports one cure at Assouan and one at Damietta. No new cases have been notified.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS found in the Matarieh district to-morrow night and at dawn of the 14th inst. will be poisoned by the police.
A LAMP ACCIDENT. — A native woman, Saieda bint Ali Khalifa by name, let fall a paraffin oil lamp yesterday whilst filling it, and was severely burnt about the head.
KHEDIVIAL MAIL S.S. Co.—We learn that that the Khedivial Mail S.S. Co. has purchased the S.S. Matabele from the Rennie Co., end that the vessel will leave London for Alexan- very shortly.
COPTIC NEW YEAR.—Yesterday being the occasion of the Neyrouz festival in honor of the Coptic new year, solemn religious service were held at the Orthodox Coptic churches of Cairo and Alexandria.

BURIED BY A FALL OF SAND.—A native workman, called Abdul Latif Mohamed, was digging a trench at Mex yesterday when the sand above him gave way and Varied him beneath it. The poor man died of snffooation.

FIGHT WITH SMUGGLERS. — In a skirmish at Alam el Teir, Marion t markaz, between Bedouin smugglers and a coastguard patrol, a Bedonin was killed, and another wounded and taken .prisoner. The coastguards seized five camels, a mare, 415 okes of gunpowder and three rifles. The remainder of the party are being pursued.

BENEFIT PERFORMANCE.- The Press of Alex-andria is organising a benefit performance on behalf of the sufferers from the recent earth quake in Calabria, which has caused great distress in one of the poorest provinces of Italy. Baron Acton, Consul General for Italy, will preside over the performance which will take place next Monday.

STREET QUARREL.—A Spaniard, named Luigi Guiseppe, and an American subject, of the name of Albert Tribnm, quarrelled in the Labban quarter yesterday. The Spaniard drew his knife and stabbed Tribnm in the abdomen, but happily did not infliot severe injuries. The would-be murderer was arrested and handed over to his consulate, and the injured man was removed to hospital.>

SAN STEFANO CASINO.—Thursday evening next will be the occasion of the last appearance at San Stefano Casino for the present season of the vocalists who have been so oh a great attraction. The ooncert will consist of the most successful pieces of their repertoire, and will doubtless be well attended to give a fitt¬ing farewell (an revoir, we trust) to these popular artistes. We will publish the pro¬gramme to morrow.

A COMPLAINT.—A resident of the Munira quarter, which is situated near the Kasr-el- Aini district of Cairo, writes to us complain¬ing that in consequence of the remissness of the Sanitary Department in not providing receptacles for refuse, as is done elsewhere, the inhabitants now make nse of the diffe rent vacant and unwalled plots of land in the neighbourhood and that in consequence, the (ffinvia from these areas ia at times unsupportable and likely to breed disease. He likewise states that the locality is seldom swept or watered by the scavenging depart¬ment

div.head: THE SOLAR FCLIPSE
div.p: LETTER FROM PROFESSOR TURNER.

Professor Turner, Savilian Professor of Astronomy, Oxford, writes to us from Cairo as follows :—Before leaving Egypt to-morrow I venture to send you a few hurried notes on the outcome of the eclipse operations BO far as they are known at present. The most note¬worthy point, perhaps, is the way in which Egypt has upheld its reputation for fine weather. From the other end of the line, Labrador, we have bad new ; apparently thick clouds prevented any observations at all. This loss untrtunatoly discounts to some extent the value of success at this end; for plates successfully taken here cannot be compared with Labrador plates for evidence of change. From Spain again we have disappointing news: the clouds did not entirely prevent observa¬tions but they have rendered their value very uncertain. Only from the other African stations have we really good news: Algeria seems to have done even better than Egypt, to judge from the enthusiastic telegram from Mr. Newall of Cambridge. We shall look forward with the greatest interest to the result of a crucial observation of Mr. Newall’s : he has tried without success at the eclipses in 1898, 1900, and 1901 to obtain evidence of the rotation of the corona, by photographing the spectrum on opposite sides of the Sun. The spectrum is extremely faint, and he requires not only fine weather but a long eclipse to get anything at all on the plates. In 1898 (India) and 1900 (Algiers) the weather was fine but the eclipse-times were short; in 1901 (Sumatra) the time was long but the weather was poor. It really seems as though there were a chance that he had got both weather and duration right this time, and if so, new facts of the greatest interest may be forthcoming. But this is not the only observation Mr. Newall was undertaking and be is quite certain to have other results of value as well. Coming to the Assouan expeditions, we may all go home well satisfied. Our plates are now developed and we can form a rough estimate of the amount of success obtained, though the ultimate verdict cannot be pro¬nounced until a good deal of measurement and other work has been done on the plates. To coned r first the possible sensation of the eclipse, the possible discovery of a new planet by on? or other of the batteries of telescopes of the American expeditions which have be¬come famous under the name of “cross-eyed ladies," I am glad to hear that Professor Hussey’s plates are all right, to a casual inspection. What the objects shown on them are, whether stars on planets, can only be determined from careful measurement and we shall not hear for some months : but the plates seem to be all right On the other hand of oourae, there are no Labrador plates to compare with them and the plates taken by Professor Campbell in Spain, whence "light clouds” are reported, may not shew the fainter objects ; for it is astonishing how little cloud it takes to "put out" faint stars. So that even if a strange object is found on Professor Hussey’s plates, it may not be possible to determine in what direction it is moving, from lack of other observations at another time. It would be distressing to have such a fleeting glimpse of a new planet and then lose it for seven year’s (there ia no suitable eclipse again until 1912) but if this rather remote con-tingency is realised there is after all the cheering thought that the honor of discovery will belong to Egypt alone. Indeed the effect of our news from other stations, so far, has been to send up the betting on our "cross¬eyed lady” as compared with the other two starters, one of which has indeed scratched altogether, if we are not misinformed. But of course the betting has been wrong sometimes. Professor Hussey has also got some fine photographs ol the corona. He can no longer hope to compare them with similar ones taken in Labrador, but they have an independent value in themselves. I may add that to the American party belongs the credit (of which Mr. Hussey has a large share) of making some very interesting observations on the shadow bands, which seem to associate their mysterious movements with the wind. So far as I know this is new and may be a distinct step, though confirmation is desirable. The Russian coronal photographs are being taken to Russia for development; but Dr. Doubinaki’s magnetograpb, taken in tomb No. 32, is developed and shews an interesting disturbance near the time of eclipse. We can¬not however say whether the association is accidental, until observations made elsewhere are collected and compared. Coming to our own work I am glad to say that polarized-light photographs come out out very well. They shew so dearly to a casual glance the strong polarization that I have little doubt the measures will give very complete information. This work is perhaps a little technical and I will not dwell on it here : but, in brief, I feel sure that the right way of going about the work has now been found, after several only partially successful trials : and a line of investigation opened up which must be definitely followed in future eclipses, until we have say at least two cycles of eleven years each. The photographs taken with the astro graphic telescope are also quite satisfactory, including the one through a green screen. Our disappointment awaited us in the big teles¬cope. There are always some disappointments at as eclipse and one most meet them philoso¬phically ; but of course it is rather distressing when they come in important pieces. The only comfort is that it was very largely out of our control. When the plates were developed the strongest image on them was that of the wood forming the plate-holder which overpowered the corona altogether. It seems to be some sort of radio-active effect, which independent of any exposure to light: for Mr Kearney put in another plate and locked up the slide in the dark-room for a day, and got just the same result on development,The cause must be carefully investigated with a view to preven¬tion in the future and we may perhaps save a worse disaster: but it is had enough as it is, especially as so many people had given us help with the big telescope and we were hoping to shew them something of interest in return. However there are, as I have said, always disappointments at eclipses : they did not spare Professor Hussey, whose most im¬portant plate, to which half the whole time ot totality was devoted, has two mysterious marks upon it. We must be thankful for the successes and not grieve over the failures unduly. We are all going home well-satisfied and deeply grateful to the country which has so hospitably guided us to success. Our indebted-ness to the Surrey Department, to the Rail¬way Administration, and to the Antiquities Department were recorded in your columns some weeks ago, but since then we have incurred many new debts of gratitude in each case. Mr. Keeling’s exertions on our behalf were never relaxed, and in the last few days were redoubled in order to get the big tele¬scope ready, and Mr. Kearney developed the plates of the British Expedition under the beat possible conditions at the Survey Depart¬ment. The Railways allowed us to put up the big telesoope at the railway station and I may add that the local fire-brigade flooded the ground for us, which would certainly have contributed largely to success if we had not been robbed of it in other ways, and we were much indebted to Mr. Hazel for help on the day of eclipse in numerous ways. But I am afraid to attempt a complete list, we had so many things done for us that it is almost impossible to remember them all, especially as many of them were done at a time when one is apt to be rather distraught. Even the weather was kind to us. Your readers may smile at the idea of anything else but I can assure you, Sir, that we took the matter more seriously On August the twenty-first it was quite cloudy all the afternoon. If the eclipse had happened on that day we should we have seen nothing at all. To consider that we had a certainty would be wrong, and the experience was valuable if only to shew what we escaped. The official welcome accorded to the expedi-tions, no only the British and American, but the Russian also, by Mr. Mitchell Innas was not only an extremely pleasant incident for those concerned but has a wider significance on which it is scarcely necessary for me to comment But I am sure neither he nor others will mind my parting word being of Captain Lyons to whom we owe more than we can say. It is four years since we first spoke of this expedition, and he immediately said he would do all he could for us. We did not know until we came to Egypt how much this meant, but we know something of it now and we also know that he has carried out his promise.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H.H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel and Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun will visit the Fayoum Agricultural Exhibition, which will be held at Medinet-el-Fayoum on the 14th, 15th, and 16th inst.
Sidky Pasha, Governor of Alexandria, is ex-pected to arrive at Budapest to-morrow from Vienna.
H. E. Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crook shank will leaves Marseilles for Port Said on 29th September per P. and 0. S.S. Persia.
Dr. E. G. Carpenter F. R. C. S., resident surgeon of Kasrel-Aini Hospital, Cairo, has resigned his appointment

Mr. Beresford Versohoyle who has been appointed engineer in chief of the Permanent Way at a salary of L.E. 7 1500 a year, is expect-ed to arrive from England in a few days time. Mr. Beresford Versohoyle is brother to Mr. J. K. Versohoyle C.M.G. one of the most distinguished officials of the Irrigation Depart-ment
As we stated in our issue of the 7th inst. Mr. Kenneth Spiers, and not Mr. Sohreiber, has been appointed secretary general to the State Railways.

We are glad to learn that the Railway Administration will mark its appreciation of the long and excellent services rendered by Mr. A. J. Cotterill and by Mr. Jmblon, who are now retiring from service, by bestowing a special pension on each of these officials.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: THE CHATHAM. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).

Port Said, Monday. The situation of the S.S. Chatham remains about the same in many ways, she being now almost completely under water, and having a slight list to starboard, though made securely fast to the Asian canal hank by heavy chains and ropes. On Saturday, I hear, a commission, which included all the canal company’s heads of departments and two British explosives experts, visited the ship, and held lengthy deliberations, the results of which are not public property. From what I gather, the great difficulty really lies in the fact that by this time the nitro¬glycerine in the dynamite, which long ago melt¬ed to a great extent, is now free in the water, with which the holds are full. This, I am told, renders all attempts at floating the vessel by pumping quite useless, and some method of raising her must be devised. Failing this it may become necessary to blow the ship up as she lies,an action which would involve thousands of pounds worth of damage to the canal and its environment. It is to be hoped that this disaster may be obviated, for it would mean the com¬plete stoppage of all traffic for some time and hundreds of other losses, commeroial and other¬wise.
FIRE ON CANAL BANK.

On Sunday columns of smoke were observed from here rising from the bank of the Canal. This, apparently, came from the dry reeds and scrub with which the fresh water canal is lined, and it is presumed that some Arabs, who are to be found thereabouts in numbers in the quail season, had carelessly allowed their camp fire to do the damage. Much of the foluge of the trees is burnt and it will be some time before this portion of the bank will be recovered with vegetation.
THE KHEDIVE.

CONSTANTINOPLE, September 8. H.H. the Khedive has decided to hire the Austrian Lloyd S.S. Dalmatia for his exele- sive use during his return from Constantinople to Alexandria. The Dalmatia is one of the beet modern vessels belonging to the company. Her hire will, it is said, amount to £1,900.

THE EGYPTIAN MARKETS COMPANY. A Cairo contemporary stated in a recent issue that in consequence of the absence of cattle plague in the country, the markets in the provinces would shortly be opened. The Sanitary Department, however, informs us that no steps can be taken towards the opening of the markets until the return of Mr. Uttlewood, chief veterinary inspector, when, should Mr Littlewood think fit to recommend it, the question will be submitted to Sir Horace Pinching on his return.

MoLean... ?/*... ... 0 A rumour is current in Cairo that a local syndicate of Syrian financiers has been formed for exploiting the new National Hotel which is just approaching completion in the Sharia Soliman Pasha at Cairo, and which has been built by Antoine Bey Sabbagh. It is farther stated that the same syndicate has built the Grand Hotel and Casino at Ain Sofar in the Lebanon from Monsieur Thial, the present proprietor, for a sum of 400,000 francs, that a new company is to be formed to work the two concerns, and that a portion of the shares will be offered for public subscription in Egypt shortly. On the other hand, we hear on what we consider good authority that the first named hotel, which is to be under the management of Mr. Branca, of the Hotel Bristol, has been acquired by a syndicate of French and Swiss capitalists.

NEWSPAPER PROSECUTION.We mentioned in our issue of the 30th ultimo that Sheik Ali Yueef, the editor and proprietor of the Cairo native paper “H Moayad," had brought a charge of attempt at blackmailing against Ahmed Fouad, the editor of the "Sayeka” or the "Thunderer, before the tribunal of Saida Zanab. We are now informed that the Parquet has submit- ted the dossier of this affair to the Pro- cureur Gdndral for examination who will decide whether the documents justify the accused being tried by the Assize Court now sitting, or the minor Tribunal above men¬tioned. In the meanwhile the case causing much talk in native journalistic circles and it is expected that some sensational disclosures will be made public when the charge comes on for hearing.

STEAMER MOVEMENTS. The Moss Liner Monee sailed from lever on the 9th inst, and is due to arrive alexandria on the 23rd inst. with pearls, nais and general cargo. The Khedivial mail a AleanaMn at Said 4 p.m Itt. Servian

div.head: CHR0N1QUE JUDICIA1RE
div.p: TRIBUNAL SOMMAIRE D’ALEXANDRII
Resiliation de bail

Un cas qui increase beaacoup de loeaUirea vient d'etre jugE par le tribunal sommaire d’Alexandria. M. Georges Pastrondia, propria taire, prEtendait avoir dounE 00DgE verbalo ment et par lettre reoommandEe k son looataire, Yonsaef Habib Hanna. Celui-ci contestant qn’an congE Ini ait EtE signifiE, l’affaire a EtE clEfErEe an tribnnal mixte. Le jnge sommaire tout en constatant l'exiatence d’nne lettre k la poate, declare qa’en FespEce il n’y a paa de congE valable dCiment Etabli, dEboute le pro prietaire de aa demands et le condamne aux dEpens.
Honoraires de medecin

Un mEdecin qai reclame pins de troote six livrea d’honoraires ponr aoins mEdioanx pro dignds k on enfant pendant une semaine, oeh paralt exagErE, aurtout loreque lea efforta de Fhomme de la science ont EohonE et n’ont pn sanver le malade. C’est sar un caa de oe genre qn’a eu k so prononoer le tribnnal sommaire d’AlexaDdrie dans sa derniere andienoe. Paraskeva Papadoponlo avait fait nne note de 3,620 P.T. pour lee soins accords par Ini an fils de M. A. B. Drevenitros. Comma oelui-ci, aprds avoir veraE an demandenr une so rotes de 976 P.T-, prEtendait Etre romplEtement lib^r6 et qne d’autre part le docteur n’aliEguait mErne pas avoir dans le re^u dElivrEde laaomme en question fait sea reserves de ne l’avoir ac-cepts qn’k titre d accompte, le tribunal, appe'E k statner, a tronvE la somme de 976 P.T. Equi¬table et suffisante ponr une semaine de soms prodiguEs k un enfant, qui d’ailieure n’en avait pas moina suowmbE malgrE les lumisres de Fhomme de l’art. Le Docteur a EtE oondamr.E anx dEpens. Voilk qui est bien.
Affaire de courtage

MM. Saleh Ahmed et oonsorts rtolamaiei t de la dame Farida bent Mohamed A bon Stete et consorts 30 £ de courtage poor nne vente immobile re dont ils an recent EtE ohargEs par mandat verbal. La dame contestant le prEtendu mandat, Saleh Ahmed a'est off art k Ie pronver par tEmoins et a citE la dame devant le tribnnal sommaire. Le jnge, ae basant sur Fart. 380 dn Code Civil, vient de dEolarer qne, le tanx de H demands exoEdant 1000 P.T., l'offre de preave par tEmoins ten dan t k Etablir l’existonoe d’un mandat, doit E re EcartEe, paroe qu’il s'agit en 1’eepEoe de matikre civile. e

div.head: Le Krach Cronier
div.p: Un eont de Pana La situation de la SociEtE des raffiueries d’Bgypte eat plus embrouiltEe qne oelle de la raffinerie Say et sera plus longue k dEnouer. De grands mEnagements sont nEoessaires en rai¬son de la situation dea obligations, notamment. La raffinerie d’Egypte anxtermea de son oontrat d’aobat des Etabliaaements snoriera de la sociEtE Egyptienne, la Daira Sanieh, doit payer k cette dernidre une annuitE de 2,830.421 franca. Faute de paiement de cette annuitE, la situation de la Raffinerie d’Bgypte deviendrait naturellement dEseapErEe. C’eat de ce cOtE qao se portent les efforts des administrateura. Mais la correspondanoe qui a EtE engagEe avec le siEge social en Egypte ne ponrra reoevoir do rEponse avant la fin de la semaine. D’antre part, il faudra envoyer nn expert eu Egypte ponr savoir comment onMtE virEs les 25 millions de traies par M. Cronier sar la sociEtE. ont-ellea EtE aealement aooeptEes pit lea admiuistrateurs pariaiens et onw-lles EtE ignorEes de la comptabilitE en Egypte 1 Suivant qne oette rEponse sera rEsolne par l’affirmative on la nEgative, la situation changera du tout an tout. D’antre part, on ne sait encore si one oonvo - cation dee aotionnairea ponr nne assemblEe gEn6rale est possible. Bn effet, la aociEtE ayant son siege an Cairo etEtant constitnEe en vertn dea lois Egyptiannea, o'est le rode de commerce Egyptien qui fixe les pon voirs. Il eat possible qua co oode ne reoonnafrae qn’an liquidateur qui aora nommE par les tri bnnaux du Cairo, le droit de oouvoquer lei aotionnaiies. On a done telegraphic poor de •mander des informations k ce snj9t Et lei administrateura et portoure de traites, ne se rEuniront qu’aprEa que les renseignementa seront venua dn Cairo. M. Cronier Etait k la fois liquidates de la socoesaion Henry Bay et da la SociEtE Henry Say et Cie. On sait que son rempla^ant poor liquidation de la succession Henry Siy, a EtE dEsignE vendredi: c’est M. Lemarquis. Lo tribunal de commerce a charge de la iiqnida tion de la SociEtE Henry Say et Cie, M ' Alexandre Gout. * Celui-ci a commencE Fexamen de la situa 1 tion. Mais il n'a pu encore, on le com prendra, arriver a auoone conclusion. La raise en faillite poathume do M. Ernest Cronier Etait k pen prEs oertaioe. Mais elle ne ponrra Etre prononoEe avant marli.

div.head: LA COMPAGNIE PENINSOLAIRE ET ORIENTALS
div.p: Dane le rapport dn conaeil d’adminiatratioi de oette oompagnie sur le3 rEsultats dn lei semnstre 1901-1905 — olos le 31 mare — le renseignemeuta suivants sont foumis sur l’Eta4 de la flotte: A la derniEre aasemblEe gEnErale, il a E'E annoneE que deux paquebots-poste, le Delhi et le Delta, de 8,000 tonnoaux ebaeun, avaient EtE commandEa. Depuia cette Epc que des or drea nouveanx ont EtE paaaEs poor la raise en chantier de deux antres unitEs du meme type, qui porteront les noma de Dongola et De vanha. On prEvoit que cea quatre batimenv entreront en exeroioe k une date prochaine ils seront apEcialement affectEs au service poa tai accElErE entre I’Inde et la Chine. Le Poona et le Peshawur (vapours de oharge de 10,000 tonnes) out EtE livrEs par leurs construoteurs et ont EtE expEdiEs sur la Chint et le Japon. Le oinquiEme paquebot du type Moldavia, le A/ixj, eutrera en service l’automne pro chain. L’agrandissement de FArcadia etdu Penin sular eat terminE; nn travail identique a’ef fectne actuellement aur VOceana et FOriental et une fois qu’il sera accompli, oes batiments Equivaudront presque k des navires neufd et seront en mesare de rEalber avec suooEs la vitesse exigEe par le oontrat postal actual. Bn tenant oompte dea navires en chantier?, b fi )tte de la Penineular and Oriental Com¬pany s’Etablissait ainsi au 31 mai dernier, date de la publication du rapport : Paquebot et vapours de charge en servioe, 54 ; tonnage brut de regiatre, 382.720 j force en chevanx vapenr effeotifs, 343,000. Navires en construction, 5 ; tonnage brut de registre, 42,000 ; foroe en ohevanx-vapeur ef fectits, 45,000. Canots et remorqueurs en service, 29 j ton¬nage brut de registre, 3,308; foroe en ohevanx- vapeur effeotifs, 922. Totaux : Navires, 88; tonnage brut de re¬giatre, 378,028 ; foroe en chevaux-vapeur effec- tife, 388.922. Le rapport expose qa'au point de vue de l'exploitation, le premier semestre de Fexer- oioe en roars n'a pas prEsentE de oontraste frappant oomparativement k la periodo oor- respondante de 1903-1904 : Tandis qne le trafio dei paasagers fait ree- aortir dea ohiffres presque identiques k oenx dn aemwtre correspondent, les enoaisaements aur le fret ont EtE pins ElevEs, par snite, prin- oipalement, d une progression dans le oom- meroe de sortie aveo la Chine etie Japon. Bn oe qui oonoerne les antres regions de l’Orient, les opErations d’sxportetion ont k peine attaint le niveau antErienr. A on moment, il semblait y avoir nne perspective d aasElioration ponr les frets de retonr ; malhenrensement cette espE ranoe ne s’est pas rEalisEe et, quant k prEaent, les affaires en retonr, prune dans Feiiseiehle, ne sont en aocane fa^on satisfaisaotoa. dn nonvean service pos¬tal Etait k peine rommencE loreque le aemes- tre en xevue a EtE clOtnrE, et la oonaommation tiupplEmantaire de char bon ainsi qne les an- tres dEpenses qni seront la oonsEquenca de I’accE'.Eration de vitesse requise snr tontes lea lignes de la Compagnie vers l’Orient, ne s’Etaient paa encore fait sentir. Anssi lea dEpen¬ses pendant lea six mois envisagEs ne prE- senteut-elles qn’ane augmentation insiguifian¬te, mais on pent a’attendre a nn accroisse- ment conaidErable pour le reste de 1’annEe. Pour assurer 1’efficaoifcE des servioes plus ra- pidea exigEs d’elle, la Compagnie a fait cons- truire rE,eminent dea paqQebots reprEsentent nne valuer de sterling 2 500.000 (62.OQ0.0GG franca) et eat en voie de dEpeoBer nne somme ronsidErable snr qnelqnes-uns des plus vienx navires de la flotte. Bn consEqnence, one addition considEtable an prElkvement annnel ponr amortissement sera nEoessaire ponr pourvoir dans nne mean re suffisante k la dEpxEoiation snr le rofit initial de la flotte. Dans leur ensemble, les rEsultats dn pre¬mier semestre 1904-1905 ont EtE satisfaieants, et le dividende de la Peninsular and Oriental Company affErent k cette portion de i’exercice a EtE maintenn, comma pendant lea deux der- niEres anuEes, an tanx moyen de 6 0,'Q Fan

div.head: SHAKE LIST
div.p: k-SCID IAs a lover of friction, I decided to pick a short story, named as “ The Road Man”, for this assignment. The story pertains to a young fellow who always noticed an elderly prophet that always carries a hefty wheelbarrow. I was very amused to this piece because I notice many similarities between the prophet and your average college student. For instance, when the narrator mentions, “ His skin, burnt almost black with sun and wind, his shaggy eyebrows and long white beard, suggest the prophets of ancient days”, reminded me of a college senior. As the prophet appears wore down from his exposure to the sun, one may compare that to how a senior appears exhausted, after years of sleep deprivation due to a tedious work load. Ironically, the narrator gave me the impression that he is a college freshman, because he is young and does not have the same years of experiences as to the prophet. Many college freshman will not understand a college seniors’ desire to undertake a tedious take due to the lack of experience. However, as the years pass by, college freshman’s will fulfill the seniors shoes, as the narrator will fill the prophet shoes. I believe this passage is very significant since it is still relevant after being composed 115 years ago.'AmAVDin”. ClOtare d'anjoard’hai k 12H.80 p.m Agrio. div.head: THE ROAD MAN.
div.p: He is old and bowed , his skin, burnt almost black with sun and wind, his shaggy eyebrows and long white beard, suggest the prophets of ancient days. Perhaps, with their opportunities, he might have been even as they. Yet here he is, with his wheelbarrow beside him, engaged in the back breaking task of patching roads. Winter and summer alike, be the weather foul or fair, he is about the lanes, doctoring them with the remedies of a hundred years ago. Our roads in this region of Suffolk are very bad, turning to inches of dust in summer and the stickiest of sticky mud in winter, and they seem likely to remain so. I come upon him suddenly, round a corner. Rain fell a days or two ago, and the surface is just becoming, for a brief period, tolerable; in fact, today, it is well enough. But the prophet is conscientious; he has detected some uneven places in the middle, and they must forthwith be filled up. The barrow is laden with stones from a heap a few hundred yards back, brittle, rotten flints, picked off the land, with nothing to recommend them but their cheapness. These will, at the slightest concussion, fly off into a dozen sharp and jagged pieces, which are, in their turn, ground up by the wheels of passing carts into a hundred smaller bits—such may possibly hare supplied the needless of the Stone Age—more subtle foes, in that the dust, which will presently cover the road, will also effectively conceal them and woe betide the unluoky cyclist who finds himself in the midst of them. The man with the motor, too, should beware ; some of them are large enough to do even him a mischief. I stop and inquire of the prophet what makes him resort to such things. His reply is to the effect that he is obeying orders, so i ask further, why such orders should be given, involving as they do the use of remedies ten times more felt than the disease itself. He pauses in his work, glad, I think, of the excuse for a moment's rest, and seats himself on his wheelbarrow. The wind is hissing pleasantly in the field of barley behind us ; we can watch the shadows racing over the marshes, and the grey aspens bending beneath the wind. It is a good place for the weighing of great matters, so I sit upon the green bank of the roadside to listen "We ha'tried granut," he begins, "times an agen we have, but thatcome expensive, an’ don't fare to be no mander o’ nse'' These are hard words; it would seem

div.head: ARTILLERY BFFIOIENCY.
div.p: A new system of testing the artillery effi¬ciency in India has been adopted by Lord Kitchener for batteries. In future, instead of a oompetition among batteries, there will be a general classification for merit, it being con¬sidered in India, as at home, that the old style of oompetition needed alteration. Thus, instead of placing batteries ia order of merit for shooting powers, they will be j adged for stable management, equitation, tarn-oat, care of material, signalling, fitness for service, laying, fuse-setting, range taking, individual intelligence, fire discipline and fire taotics, and fire effect. In most of these items the marks will range from 30 to 60, bat for the last two the award will be 300 marks each. The practice of batteries is divided into “instruction,” "test,” and "brigade” stages. In the first stage batteries will be kept until they are fit to prooeed to the testing or the the work in brigade. The interest of the men will be secured in their batteries, not for a short competitive period, but for every day of the year, and no manner of work in a battery will be allowed to remain as non-mark earning. A battery will be judged upon its whole fitness, and not upon the special preparation inseparable from a oompetition.

div.head: HOSPITABLE GERMANS.
div.p: Seine of the German newspapers—not the most influential and responsible of them, by any means—which aTe still under the impres¬sion that ft.juts and jeers at Ragland are popu¬lar with their readers, have fonnd, or at any rate sought, an opportunity in the visit of the Channel Fleet to the Baltic coasts. Their theory that this will gratify the German pnblio (writes a correspondent cf a London paper) ia perhaps erroneous. I have heard a good deal of indignation expressed at the journalistic at¬tempts to oreate ill feeling between the two countries. Some of the statements which have been made in the German Press, and repeated in England, are certainly inoorrect and even abrard. Thus it was said that such cheering as was heard at Swinemunde was due entirely to the efforts of English tonrists who "crowded into” the town. There is no truth in the statement. I was at Swinemuude from Sunday till Wednesday, with my eyes and ears well open all the time, and I will undertake to say that there were not forty English viaitore in the place, at an outside estimate. Another of these journalistic fantaisies is that the German visitors to Swinemuude com¬mented freely on the dirty and nntidy appear anoe of the British ships, and on the lax disci- M pline that prevailed. They are said to have found rubbish lying about the deoks, gun ooufosion of the Teutonic intelligence. The men and the officers of the German navy, apart from the superficial differences of dress and manner, are strangely like our own. As yoa walk about the oraaped streets of old Kiel, and the leafy avenaee of the new town, you see face after hoe, whioh is snore charact nitiaally "Angto-Baxoe” then TOO will « Zwgund am Ho' give an order in the pleasant conversational ti ne in which, let us say, the exptain of a wicket eleven might tell point to stand a little farther out In the German navy they have the army manner j and in all armies, including onr own, it is assumed that the man who gives a oommand has a throat of brass, and the man who receives it ears of wood. Two unique assets we possess. One is that large experience of the sea, under varied con¬ditions, whioh our world-wide Empire and our unequalled geographical situation enable ns to give our men. The German "Evolution¬ary Squadron” is often in harbour, and it knows, at best, only a small segment of the water-surfaoe of the globe. Nor do the Germans yet venture to fix responsibility and give power at the same early age as onrs^lvg*. Their junior lieutenants are very young, hut thiy are not boys like our midshipmen. Great, indeed, was the astonishment of the spectators on the Swinemunde "Bollwerk” when a donble- funnelled steam pinnace oame alongside under the oommand of one of these young gentlemen. He looked a mere child, with a pretty, soft, downy face like« girl’s. I heard a motherly German woman express an audible desire to take him up and kiss him. The middy did not understand the remark, but he would not have been oonfosed if be had. The crowd on the wharf wu nothing to him. He had his business to attend to. The boat was filled with cooked bate and laoed ooata, for it WM land¬ing captains and commanders for the municipal fote; bat they paid no attention to the management OT navigation of the little steamer. The youngtter out of the school-room would see after that, of coarse. div.head: THE CHOLERA SCARE.
div.p: The cholera outbreak reported from the Continent will have very little, if any, chance of pervading England. Active preparations have been made by the Port Sanitary Authority, through the medical officer’s department, for conducting the mediaal examination of shipping at Gravesend. Particular attention will be paid to the inspection of vessels arriving from ports where the diaeare was known, or sus¬pected to exist It will be remembered that in the early part of last year many towns in Persia and along the shores of tbs Persian Gulf as far as Manat were affected. During June, 1904, the was carried across the frontier from aggastave of oholen ha is at onoe aecosdanoa with the degrae of sfcgtinsi DisaeM is spread m aumy ways. The chief >U WU.VU UIO process oi extermination is employed era down the river, comprising mendstion of a work whioh can show snoh satisfactory results. No one doubts that the extermination of so many thousands of these pests removes one of the most dangerous spreading factors. In view of the suooess aohieved, the practice will be vigorously main tained. It is as safe a guarantee as oonld possibly be obtained of the prevention of a oholeraio outbreak in London from Continental souroes. The Port Sanitary Authority’s offi¬cials declare that DO effort will be spared in preventing cholera-infected people from passing up the Thames to Ixmdon. Iu addition to the Medical Offioer-in-Chief there are four boarding medical offiiers—two at Gravesend and two at SheerneM - besides other inspeo ton, Every person coming into port will be •temined, and the authorities will satisfy themrelves that all infected material has been destroyed. There ia no reason for serious alarm in London. Up to the present the out¬break seems to have got no farther than Hamburg, where it stopped last year.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

div.p: (EGYPT), LIMITED, HEAD OFFICE—LUDGATE CIRCUS—LONDON.
CHIEF EGYPTIAN OFFICE — CAIRO, near SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL.
Alexandria, Port-Said, Suez, Luxor, Assuan, Haifa, & Khartum.
GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.

Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
